cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to film form (including style and narration), different types of films, and popular approaches to the study of cinema. Topics include: narrative cinema, documentary, avant-garde, genre, authorship, ideology, and representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Film Study

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and discussion are online synchronous. Screenings will be online asynchronous. Students need internet connection, access to a web camera, and microphone for participation in online discussions.

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on special topics in Cinema Studies. Topics vary each year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Both lectures and discussions will be live-streamed and recorded (permitting both synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) as per the meeting schedule. However, synchronous attendance will be necessary for participation grades, and asynchronous participation should be limited to either catching up on or reviewing materials. Weekly screenings will be online and asynchronous via MyMedia. Students will need a web camera, microphone, and high-speed internet connection for video conferencing, media screenings, and access to Quercus (discussion boards, BB collaborate, etc.).

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on special topics in Cinema Studies. Topics vary each year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Asynchronous lectures will be posted online each week via links posted to Quercus. Asynchronous screenings will be posted on Quercus as streaming links. A synchronous pre-screening discussion will take place as per the meeting time prior to each screening either on Zoom or on BB Collaborate through Quercus. Students need access to a computer with Internet access, a microphone, and ideally, a webcam.

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: From Buddy Film to Bromance: Homoeroticism in Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on selected topics in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "New Media."
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Cinema Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online synchronously per meeting schedule. Screenings will be online and asynchronous, but will be coordinated with lectures. Students need access to high-speed internet service and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on selected topics in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "New Media."
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Cinema Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Discussion meetings will be online synchronous as per meeting schedule; students are required to attend the live discussion. Lectures and screenings will be online asynchronous. Students need high-speed internet for streaming and video conferencing, access to a web camera and microphone, and the ability to use functions within Quercus (e.g., submitting Assignments, accessing files, participating in Discussion Boards, and operating BB Collaborate, etc.).

courses.name: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Learning the Unteachable: Cinema and Aesthetic Education

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online synchronous and will include PowerPoint presentations, film clips, and in-class discussions. Live-streamed lectures will be recorded, but synchronous participation is mandatory. Screenings will be online asynchronous and can be accessed through the course website. Students will need a computer, webcam, microphone, and high-speed internet access to use Quercus and BB Collaborate.

courses.name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism

sections.name: LEC5101
sections.subTitle: The Audience Walks Out: Difficulty, Estrangement, and Modernism at the Movies

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "Cinema and Intermediality."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and discussion periods will be delivered synchronously through Quercus per the meeting schedule. Films will be made available through Quercus one week prior to class for asynchronous viewing. Students will need access to high-speed internet, a web camera, and microphone to participate in Blackboard Collaborate discussions.

courses.name: Special Topics in History and Nation

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Clash on Screen: Multiculturalism in Recent European Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in History and Nation

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online synchronous and followed by class discussion in seminar format. While lectures will be recorded, synchronous attendance and participation are mandatory. Screenings will be asynchronous and accessible through Quercus. Students will need a steady internet connection, a functional webcam, and microphone to access screenings as well as Zoom and PowerPoint, which are downloadable applications through the University of Toronto.

cmCourseInfo.description: See course description for CIN492H1 listed below. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies in Cinema
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least ten full-course equivalents, including CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, CIN301Y1/ permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Please note: Students must complete CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, and CIN301Y1 before taking any fourth year Cinema Studies courses. For "E" indicator Cinema Studies Courses: Contact the Undergraduate Assistant, 416-978-8571, cinema.studies@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Independent research projects devised by students and supervised by Cinema Studies faculty. Open to advanced Specialist and Major students in the Program. Submit applications to the Undergraduate Program Office: Fall 2016 courses, June 1/ Winter 2017 courses, November 1/ Summer 2017 courses, April 1. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
